children.text: The Chevrolet Bel Air is a full-size vehicle produced from 195o through 1981 (model years) through seven generations. From 1950 to 1952, initially just the two-door hardtop Chevrolet models carried the Bel Air name. Starting for the 1953 model year, Bel Air was considered a premium trim level for multiple body styles across the Chevrolet lineup until 1975 when the United States pulled the plug on production. Canada continued building the Bel Air for its local market all the through the 1981 model year.
First-Generation (1950 - 1954)

For the 1950 model year, the Chevy Bel Air Hardtop was fashioned as a convertible but featured a firm non-removable roof. Although similar models have been floating around since the 1920s, the design never seemed to take off. This time, the style would prove revolutionary for decades to come even making its way to other brands under the General Motors umbrella, including Cadillac.

Only 76,662 examples of the 1950 Chevy Bel Airs were produced for the initial 1950 model year as people were trying out this new design concept. The car was priced at $1,741, weighed in at 3,225 pounds, and featured independent front suspension known as "knee-action".

The early model Bel Airs shared the same windshield, doors, glass, and trunk with the Styline DeLuxe Convertible Coupe with the back half of the car (after the A-pillar) was unique to the model such as the roof, rear quarters, and rear windows. The car did share the chassis, mechanicals, and overall appearance with the rest of the lineup, but it did feature a lower roof line and a unique three-piece rear window. Only "DeLuxe" premium trim level and specifications were attached to the Bel Air name.

For 1951 and 1952, the Bel Air had a few differences from the initial 195o model such as higher rear guards that appeared with more of a squared appearance, a feature that could be found across the entire lineup. Of course, the normal trim and grille changes were apparent.

For the 1953 model year, Chevrolet moved the Bel Air moniker to more premium models. Chevrolet just renamed the series, and the lower models were called the 150 and 210, replacements for the Special and Deluxe. The 1953 model was marketed as "Entirely new and through and through" with the body panels, rear end, and front end all redesigned. Cosmetically the car had changed, but it still shared similar frame and mechanicals with the 1949 - 1952 model years.

The 1953 and 1954 Chevrolets went through an awkward appearance stage as the cars were in the midst of a transformation with necessary changes implemented that would ultimately be the iconic 1955 - 1957 Chevy Bel Air. Chevrolet terminated the torque tube drive, six-cylinder splash feed engines, knee action suspension, split windshields found in the pre-war models. The bases for the initial post-war modern Chevrolet passenger car were established in the 1953 - 1954 model, which featured molding in the form of a wide chrome stripe that ran from the rear fender bulge to the rear bumper, a body color-matched inside stripe, and "Bel Air" script. The lower models were not adorned with names or badging, just the Chevrolet crest attached to the trunk and hood. A one-piece curved windshield was introduced for the 1953 model year. The 1953 Bel Air was tested in the July 1953 issue of
Popular Mechanics
where it went from o to 60 mph in 19.6 seconds.

Inside, the interior of the Bel Airs were overloaded with chrome such as the optional lower part of the dashboard (most were painted) to the deluxe Bel Air steering wheel with a full chrome horn ring. Standard equipment included full wheel covers and carpeting. For the 1954 model, the Bel Air was given updated taillights and grille in regards to cosmetics. Performance-wise, the engine was revised to include insert bearings and increased oil pressure which was necessary for the new full-flow oil filtration system for 1954. Before, the car was powered by 235-cubic-inch and 216-cubic-inch V6 engines complete with babbit bearings and scoops that created oil pressure at eh bottom of each rod with a standard psi sitting between 15 - 30.

Three engine options were available depending on the transmission of choice. Two "Blue Flame" 235-cubic-inch OHV inline-six engines were available and were equipped with hydraulic valve lifters (for 1953 model year with an automatic) and aluminum pistons. Manual cars came with a standard 235ci engine with solid lifters and splash along with pressure lubrication such as babbit bearings. If equipped with a Powerglide, the engine was equipped with hydraulic lifters and full pressure lubication, and it was capable of 115-horsepower.

The 1953 and 1954 Bel Airs were offered in convertible and a hardtop coupe, and came with either two or four doors. The 1954 Beauville station wagon's side windows came adorned with woodgrain trim. Options that were once saved for more expensive cars were implemented on the 1953 Bel Air model including power steering and Guidematic headlight dimmer. For 1954, additional options were added such as power brakes, power 2-way front seat, and power windows. Standard transmission used in the 1954 models utilized the Powerglide engine from the 1953 model year.
Second-Generation (1955 - 1957)

The second-generation Chevrolets are commonly referred to as "Tri Fives". For the 1955 model year, the Bel Air was overhauled in design and performance. Dubbed the "Hot One" in GM's advertising campaign, the new Bel Air weighed in at 3,456 pounds and measured 15-feet long. Up front, the grille was inspired by Ferrari, and was given smooth, crisp body lines along the body. The Bel Air has everything given to lesser models but additional options included chrome headliner bands on hardtops, chrome spears on front fenders, interior carpet, stainless steel window moldings, and full wheel covers. The Bel Air could be differentiated from other models with "Bel Air" in gold lettering on models produced later in the year.

Performance-wise, a 265-cubic-inch (4.3-liter) V8 option was added to the lineup that came backed by a 2-speed Powerglide automatic transmission or 3-speed Synchro-Mesh manual transmission with overdrive optional. Mechanical highlights included a modern, overhead-valve high-compression ratio, and a short-stroke design (that remained in several displacement engine option for multiple decades). Rated at 162-horsepower, the base V8 was fed by a two-barrel carburetor, but a "Power Pack" option was available which included a four-barrel carburetor and other upgrades to produce 180-brake-horsepower. Introduced later in the year was the "Super Power Pack" option had even higher compression and bumped the output to 195-brake-horsepower. The generator and oil pressure lights were replaced by "idiot" lights. The first Chevy V8 was implemented in the Series D that debuted in 1917 and was built for two years, which was back before the Bel Air and before Chevrolet became a part of General Motors.
A little faster than before,
Popular Mechanics

tested the new V8 and reported that the V8 Bel Air with a Powerglide could scoot from 0 to 60 mph in 12.9 seconds in comfort with good visibility. However, the horn ring blocked a portion of the speedometer, the engine knocked on regular gasoline, and the very first V8 engines burned too much oil.
Motor Trend

praised the car for its handling capabilities. Braking was handled by 11-inch drums. More new options in the V8-powered 1955 Bel Air models included air conditioning, outlets on both sides of the dashboard, and a heavy-duty generator. Previous 1955 and 1956 models could be given air conditioning if equipped with the standard 3-speed manual, overdrive or Powerglide. After 1957, an automatic was required.

For the 1956 model year, the Bel Air was given a fresh face with a conventional full-width grille that replaced the Ferrari-inspired front end for 1955. Other changes included the addition of the iconic two-tone body and wheel openings in the front and rear. The rear featured single housings that included the taillight, stop light, and backup light, with the left housing holding the gas filler which was a popular on Cadillacs. A new Sport Sedan was added which was a four-door hardtop without pillars. Over 103,000 of these Sport Sedans were produced along with 128,000 hardtop models. Just 7,886 two-door Nomad wagons were built with a $2,608 - the highest priced model - and it featured the same interior and rear-sheet metal as the Bel Air.

The least expensive Bel Air option was the two-door sedan priced at $2,025. Features included seatbelts, shoulder harnesses, and a padded dashboard, and the full-sized vehicles could be optioned with the 225-horsepower engine also utilized in the Corvette.

For 1956, an option for the Bel Air was the rain-sensing automatic top that was first seen on Buick's 1951 LeSabre concept car (which some believe was never actually installed on the car). Only 7.4 percent of people actually ordered seatbelts according to
Popular Mechanics
. Chevy engineer Zora Arkus Duntov prepared a '56 Bel Air 4-door hardtop that dominated Pikes Peak with a new endurance and speed record.

For the 1957 model year, a larger 283-cubic-inch (4.6-liter) V8 engine was available with the "Super Turbo Fire V8" option that was also shared with the Corvette. With the help of a Rochester Ramjet continuous mechanical fuel injection (closed-loop), the Bel Air could generate 283-horsepower (6200-rpm) and 290 lb/ft of torque (4400-rpm). These were also known as "fuelie" cars, which are considered rare since most Bel Airs are fed by carburetors.

One of the most recognizable American cars of all time is the 1957 Chevy Bel Air, which is considered an icon to many. The '57 models are highly desired, especially Sport Coupes and Convertibles. Utilizing period tail fins and an abundance of chrome, the cars were extremely roomy. A new optional Turboglide automatic transmission was added and offered continuously variable gear-ratio which made "shifting" imperceptible. The original 2-speed Powerglide remained unchanged. Turboglide cars featured a "P R N D Gr" pattern for shifting.

The two-door Nomad station wagon was given the Bel Air name from 1955 to 1957, although it had its own unique body and trim. In 1954 before the Nomad became a production model, it was a concept car based on the Corvette. Two concept cars have been unveiled by Chevy given the Nomad name with the latest in 1999.

Also available in right-hand-drive, the 1955 - 1957 Bel Airs were  955 through 1957  were shipped from Oshawa, Canada to be assembled locally in New Zealand, South Africa, and Australia. A reversed version of the '55 Bel Air's left-hand-drive dashboard was given to these three model years, and they did not feature the redesign given to the '57 model year.
The 1973 movie
American Graffiti

featured a black 1955 Chevy Bel Air driven by Harrison Ford's character Bob Falfa. In the film, the '55 - equipped with a large 454-cubic-inch Chevy V8 motor with aluminum heads, a tunnel ram intake, and twin Holley carburetors - races a yellow '32 Ford Deuce Coupe and wrecks into a ditch.
Third-Generation (1958)

The third-generation Chevrolet model was for the standalone 1958 model year. Redesigned to be longer, lower, and heavier than previous models, the '58 Bel Air featured the first production Chevy big-block - a 348-cubic-inch (5.7-liter) V8 - as an option. Even more, the 1958 Bel Air received a halo vehicle - the Impala - which was only available as hardtop or convertible for the first model year. The Impala featured many of the basic characteristics given to Chevy vehicles but had its own style including a different roof line, vent above the rear window, special side trim, and broader alcoves that housed triple tail lights. Those looking to spend less could opt for the Biscayne (previously the 21o) and the Delray (formerly the 150).

Chevrolet proved better than other brands under General Motors for the 1958 model year. Unlike other offerings, Chevy didn't overload the lineup with chrome found on Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick, and Cadillac models. Simulating the "Baby Cadillac" was the broad grille and quad headlights found up front. Dual taillights could be found out back along with a fan-shaped alcove on the tail on both side panels.

Although it was a recession year, Chevrolet was number one with the Bel Air topping the list of popular vehicles. With plenty of body styles and models to choose from, the Bel Air offered every luxury option offered on the Chevrolet lineup. For 1958, the Nomad made a triumphant return.

New for the 1958 model year was Chevrolet's new "Safety-Girder" cruciform frame. This new "x-frame" was similar to the 1957 Cadillac layout and was equipped with box-section side rails and a boxed front cross member under the engine. Used on Chevys (and Cadillac) from 1958 through 1964, a channel-section cross member tied together the rear. Later, this design was criticized as providing less protection during a side impact crash. Powerglide models featured the "PRNDL" transmission arrangement for the first time which replaced the "PNDLR" quadrant that many found confusing.
Fourth-Generation (1959 - 1960)

For the fourth-generation, Chevrolet debuted a completely new car for the second time. The new 1959 Chevy model looked nothing like anything else produced with ultra-low headlights and cat's-eye tail lights. Even more, the brand new car was given a new series name and had new sheetmetal atop a new frame. The biggest visual difference was the flat, wing-shaped tail fins.

Built on a 119-inch wheelbase, the car measured 211 inches long (11 inches longer than the 1957 model) which made the model the longest offered in a low-price range. The 1959 model was 3 inches wider on the exterior and 5 inches wider on the inside. The car still sat atop the x-frame, but it was strengthened and enlarged.

Once topping the series totem pole, the Bel Air was now considered middle range. Wagons were in their very own class but still had model numbers within the series. Bel Air model numbers were given to middle-range Parkwood (6-passenger) and Kingswood (9-passenger).

Not much changed in the performance department with plenty of speed options available. The combination of fuel injection, special cams, and lowered compression bumped the output to 315-horsepower. Production was high with 447,100 example produced, but the Impala line surpassed that number by 20,000 units. Also, a parking brake warning light became optional.

For the 1960 model year, little changes were made besides minor refinements that were given to the 1959 model year. A more restrained front end, and double-cone tail lights instead of "cat's eyes" were features given to the 1959 model year. Under the hood, everything remained the same except that fuel injection was no longer available. A 348-cubic-inch V8 engine allowed for 335-horsepower (5800-rpm) thanks to three double-barrel carburetors, a special cam, and an 11.25:1 compression ratio.

The 1960 body continued from the 1959 model year with Chevrolet now offering hardtops and sedans. Only the Impala series received a convertible version. The Bel Air Sport Sedan still implemented the rear window overhang and a large wraparound rear window, and out back two tail lights per side along with the Biscayne with Impalas using three per side (continuous through 1975). The Bel Air and Impala still shared many of the same options and accessories. More interior and exterior brightwork was given to the Bel Air over the Biscayne.
Fifth-Generation (1961 - 1964)

Again, Chevrolet debuted a completely new body for the 1961 model year. More than just sheetmetal, the wheelbase stayed at 119 inches but length decreased to 209.3 inches. Power options stayed in place from the previous year and generation with standard engines including the 235.5-cubic-inch six-cylinder (135-hp) oe the 283-cubic-inch V8 (170-hp). The larger V8 option was $110 more than the six-cylinder, and weighed less by just 5 pounds.

Chevrolet's Bel Air two-door sedan featured a squared-off roof design with a large wraparound window (unlike the hardtop's swept-back style). The four-door Bel Air Sport hardtop still featured a different roofline than the four-door sedan model.

The 1962 model was given new sheetmetal on the door panels with everything else remaining the same. Body length increased to 209.6 inches, and the Bel Air series no longer included the 4-door Sport Hardtop. Standard powerplants remained the same from the previous year but a new 327-cubic-inch V8 (250-hp or 300-hp) and a massive 409-cubic-inch V8 engine (380-hp or 409-hp) with a dual four-barrel carburetor setup were added to the lineup. The separate wagon class was discontinued with each one a four-door model under the Biscayne, Bel Air, or Impala name. Standard equipment now included full carpeting on all 1962 Bel Air models for the first time in years, and this was the final year of the Bel Air Sport Coupe being produced for the U.S. market. The Sport Coupe was given the roofline of the '61 hardtop coupe.

The 1963 model year saw a few changes including length being increased to 210.4 inches. A more modern 230-cubic-inch V6 engine with a rating of 140-horsepower replaced the older 235ci, and it was based off the compact Chevy II Nova from the prior year. The base V8 remained the same (283ci) but was upgraded with an output of 195-horsepower, and the 409ci V8 was offered with 340-, 400-, and 425-horsepower versions. Continuing on was the small-block 327ci V8 with a rating of 250-hp and 300-horsepower.

Still considered a middle range vehicle, the Bel Air now only featured two car models - a two-door and four-door sedan. Again, six-passenger and nine-passenger Bel Air station wagons were also available.

The 1964 model year saw little change except for normal sheetmetal and trim updates. This time, the car measured 209.9 inches long with wagons measuring 210.8 inches in length. Standard engines remained the same but two new 327-cubic-inch engines were offered from 250-horsepower to 300-horsepower and three 409-cubic-inch V8 engines were available that ranged from 340-hp to 425-hp. The only thing changed was the chrome belt line and the $100 price difference between Biscayne and Bel Air models.

Right-hand-drive Bel Air models still were being imported into Australia with some cars featuring a reversed instrument panel from a 1961 Pontiac while others still had the North American panel. A few of the imported Bel Airs were equipped with Impala-style triple taillights with the center lens being amber to adhere to Australian laws.
Sixth-Generation (1965 - 1970)

Starting the sixth-generation, the full-sized Chevrolets were completely redesigned for the 1965 model. Length increased to 213.3 inches, but the car still retained the same wheelbase. Up front, the car was given a new stamped grille along with a lower extension below the bumper. The window glass was curved, and high-mounted round taillights were changes made to the 1964 model. Interior was redesigned, and the car was given an attractive new dashboard. Standard engines remained the same but new options joined the ranks including a 396-cubic-inch (325-hp) and two 409-cubic-inch blocks (400-hp and 425-hp).

Exterior-wise, the Bel Air featured a stainless-steel belt and rocker molding, a distinctive signature on the rear fenders, and a glove compartment light. A power tailgate was given to 9-passenger wagons as opposed to the lower-model Biscayne.

The 1966 model year only received mild changes that involved forward-thrusting blunted front fenders along with a grille revision. Out back, the Bel Air and Biscayne both came equipped with rectangular tail lamps with integrated back-up lamps. Overall, the car measured in at 213.2 inches. A larger 250-cubic-inch six-cylinder engine was now standard with an output of 155-horsepower. Also, a new 427-cubic-inch V8 (390-hp or 425-hp) was optional. The Bel Air could be distinguishable from the Biscayne by the full length body side molding and Bel Air signatures in the rear fenders. Now standard on wagons was an all-vinyl interior, and cloth with vinyl trim could be found inside sedan models.

The 1967 model year full-sized Chevrolet models were given a new body complete with bulging rear fenders. The two-door and four-door Bel Air sedans remained in production along with the wagons (6-passenger and 9-passenger). Triple taillights were given to the Bel Air while the Biscayne featured twin units. The same standard engines remained in place from the previous year with options including the 396-cubic-inch V8 (350-hp) or 427-cubic-inch V8 (385-hp) along with plenty of speed packages to choose from.

Still similar to the 1967 model, the 1968 full-size Chevrolet received some changes. The length was drawn out to 214.7 inches and a new grille design was reminiscent of a Cadillac. For the first time, the Bel Air's dual round taillights were mounted in the rear bumper.

Additional safety features were now required by the 1968 model year in all motor vehicles, along with shoulder belts for those occupying the front seats along with side marker lights. Emblems showing the optional V8 size now were displayed as part of the front side marker lights
In addition to the 250 CID Six of 155 hp (116 kW), standard engines included the new
V8 of 200 hp (150 kW). The Bel Air with the standard 250 Six was capable of a top speed of 90 mph (140 km/h) and 18.4 mpg
‑US
‑imp
) at cruising speeds. When powered by the new 307 CID V8, the Bel Air series cars had a top speed of 105 mph (169 km/h) and 17.1 mpg
‑US
‑imp
) at cruising speeds.
1969 Chevrolet Bel Air 2-door Sedan

For 1969, the big Chevrolet was totally redesigned, given a new length, new fender and body lines, and a new front and back end, but continued using the basic 1965 chassis, innerbody structure and even the rooflines of pillared two- and four-door sedans. The cars also remained on the 119 in (3,000 mm) wheelbase, but grew to a new length of 219.9 in (5,590 mm), while the wagons grew 4.3 in (110 mm) to a new length of 217.7 Engine offerings included a standard 250 cubic-inch six-cylinder and 235 hp (175 kW) 327 V-8, and optional V-8 engines included two 350s of 255 hp (190 kW) and 300 hp (220 kW), a 396 rated at 265 hp (198 kW) and three 427 V8s of 335 hp (250 kW), 390 hp (290 kW), and 425 hp (317 kW). This was the final year for the Bel Air 2-door sedan and the Bel Air-based station wagon was renamed Townsman, as part of a Chevrolet move to revert to the pre-1962 practice of using different nameplates on station wagons than other models. Three- and four-speed manual transmissions were again offered along with the two-speed Powerglide automatic with the six-cylinder, and 327 and 350 V-8s; and the three-speed Turbo Hydramatic, offered only with the big-block V-8s since its 1965 introduction, was now available with all engines.

For 1970, the Chevrolet line was very little changed and regulated primarily to a new and very attractive front end. The standard Six was still the 250 of 155 hp (116 kW). The standard V8 in full-size Chevrolets was now the
of 250 hp (190 kW). Optional V-8 engines included a 300 hp (220 kW) 350 and 265 hp (198 kW) 400, with the top offering a
of 345 hp (257 kW). The Bel Air series was now a one model 4-door sedan while the station wagon was again sold under the Townsman nameplate.
GM B platform
is the fourth best selling automobile platform in history after the
Volkswagen Beetle
Ford Model T
and the
Lada Riva
Seventh generation (1971–1975)
